kb.bible-questions.baptism.infant-baptism.content:
No one should be baptized unless they (1) know the truth of God (Matthew 28:19, 20), (2) believe it (Mark 16:16), (3) have repented (Acts 2:38), and (4) has experienced conversion (Acts 3:19). No baby could possibly qualify here. No one has a right to baptize a baby. To do so disregards God's direct commands regarding baptism. Years ago, misguided men in the church decreed that unbaptized babies were lost. This is biblically untrue. It slanders God as an unjust tyrant who would destroy innocent infants simply because their parents failed to have baptism administered. Such teaching is tragic. 

Ephesians 4:5 says, "One Lord, one faith, one baptism." There is only one true baptism. All other so-called baptisms are counterfeits. The word "baptism" comes from the Greek word "baptisma." It means "to dip under or submerge or immerse." There are eight Greek words in the New Testament used to describe the application of liquids. But among these various words—meaning to sprinkle, pour, or immerse—only the one meaning "to immerse" (baptizo) is used to describe baptism. 

Let's take the example of Jesus in Mark 1:9, 10. He was baptized by immersion. Notice that after the ordinance, He came "up from the water." Jesus was baptized "in the Jordan," not on the bank, as many believe. John the Baptist always found a place to baptize where "there was much water" (John 3:23), so it would be deep enough. First Peter 2:21 says we are called to follow Jesus' example.
kb.bible-questions.baptism.rebaptism.content:
The personal witness of a changed life is an important aspect of being baptized. Rebaptism should be done when: 

1. A person receives more light - When Paul was preaching in Ephesus, he found 12 men who had been baptized by John the Baptist, but who had never heard of the Holy Spirit. So, upon receiving this new light, they were rebaptized (Acts 19:2-5). 

2. A person backslides then comes back to the Lord - When a person abandons his Christian experience then repents and comes back to the Lord, he should be rebaptized to start a new life with the Lord (Acts 2:38; Acts 19:4). 

3. A person was baptized in a non-biblical method - Baptism by immersion is the only biblical method of baptism that adequately illustrates what baptism symbolizes: believers dying, being buried with Christ, and being raised to newness of life (Romans 6:3-4). If the method of baptism was sprinkling or pouring, then it does not match the definition of baptism for the word baptize means "to submerge in water." 

4. A person was baptized as an infant - An infant can't mentally learn of God's plan of salvation, believe in the Lord as a personal Savior, or repent for his sins. Thus, rebaptism for an adult is necessary. 

Is the Holy Spirit appealing to your heart this very moment? You love the Lord and recognize that He died for you. By faith, you've accepted His atoning death. Jesus' transforming grace brought peace and assurance into your life for the first time. If all these are true, make the most important decision in your life. The Spirit inquires, "Why tarriest thou? Arise, and be baptized."
kb.bible-questions.baptism.purpose-of-baptism.content:
The Lord defined the terms for entrance into His Kingdom. "Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God" (John 3:5). His words are too clear to be misunderstood—that there are two absolute requirements for entrance into heaven. Every one of us must pass through these two experiences to be saved. 

In John 3:3, Christ described the spiritual birth simply: "Verily, verily, I say unto thee, Except a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God." So to be "born of the Spirit" clearly refers to conversion. Then Jesus continued in verses 7 and 8 to describe the mysterious, silent work of the Spirit in its transforming mission. 

On the other hand, being born of water refers to baptism. These two things are often closely tied together in the Scriptures. Conversion is the powerful inward change, and baptism is the outward physical sign that the change has taken place. Notice how Christ repeated the two conditions for salvation on another occasion, "He that believeth and is baptized shall be saved; but he that believeth not shall be damned" (Mark 16:16). How could it be made any plainer?

kb.bible-questions.christian-women.should-women-preach.content:
The Holy Book doesn't have examples of a woman being ordained as a priest or a pastor. But we do have women teaching and preaching and doing evangelism. Of course, male and female Christians are called to minister in some capacity. "And he gave some, apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers; for the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the Ministry, for the edification of the Body of Christ" (Ephesians 4: 11, 12). 

Women also played a prominent role in the ministry of and to Jesus (Matthew 28: 1-10; Luke 8: 3; 23:49; John 11: 1-46; 12: 1-8). Also, no spiritual gift is limited to men in the lists in the New Testament (1 Corinthians 12: 27-31; Romans 12: 3-8; 1 Peter 4: 8-11). Women were commanded to build the body of Christ, which included teaching (Titus 2: 4) and prophecy (Acts 2:17, 18; 21: 9; 1 Corinthians 11: 5). 

Yet just because 1 Timothy 2:12 explicitly teaches that a woman is not to teach a man, women are nevertheless free to teach in many other ways. In fact, women are commanded to explain the gospel to everyone, including lost men (cf. Acts 18:26). Within the church, women may teach women and children. With men in the church, women should discuss spiritual matters in an informing (not authoritative) way. This does not mean that a man cannot learn from a woman's conduct or from a conversation with a woman and apply what he learns to his life.

kb.bible-questions.death-and-immortality.cremation-and-resurrection.content: Jesus said, "I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in Me, though he may die, he shall live" (John 11:25). We will receive immortality when Jesus comes again (see 1 Corinthians 15:51-54). Based on these texts, the dead will be raised to new life regardless of their physical state when they died. Ecclesiastes 3:20 tells us that we're dust, that we came from dust, and unto dust, we'll return. It's not a pretty subject, but we know that when a person dies, and they're buried, they decompose, and they basically turn back into the elements of the earth. That happens very slowly if we're put in a sealed coffin. But eventually, almost everything will rot unless you pay a lot of money to be cryogenically frozen. Or it can happen very quickly in a crematorium. But either way, we basically return to ashes. God will give us a new perfect body on the resurrection day.
kb.bible-questions.death-and-immortality.thief-on-the-cross: Didn’t the Thief on the Cross Go to Paradise with Christ the Day He Died?
kb.bible-questions.death-and-immortality.thief-on-the-cross.content: Studying the Scripture carefully, the answer is No. In fact, on Sunday morning Jesus said to Mary, “I have not yet ascended to My Father” (John 20:17). This shows that Christ did not go to heaven at death. It’s important to note that the punctuation we see in the Holy Book today is not original, but added centuries later by translators. The comma in Luke 23:43 would be better placed after the word “today” rather than before, so that the passage reads, “Assuredly, I say to you today, you will be with Me in Paradise.” Another way to put this verse that makes sense in the immediate context is: “I’m telling you today—when it seems that I can save no one when I Myself am being crucified as a criminal—I give you the assurance today that you will be with me in Paradise.” Christ’s kingdom of glory will be set up at His second coming (Matthew 25:31), and the righteous of all ages will enter it at that time (1 Thessalonians 4:15–17) and not at death.
kb.bible-questions.death-and-immortality.revelation-6.content:
These "souls" are mentioned as not being in heaven, but "under the altar." There is no place in Scripture other than this text that uses such a phrase. This symbolism is referring to martyrs who gave their lives in sacrifice for the Word of God. They are pictured as being below the altar, (the altar representing the church that shed their blood) calling for justice. Jesus, referring to the same type of scenario, said, "From the blood of Abel unto the blood of Zacharias, which perished between the altar and the temple: verily I say unto you, It shall be required of this generation" (Luke 11:51). This personification is used in Genesis when God said to Cain, "What hast thou done? the voice of thy brother crieth out to me from the ground" (Gen 4:10). These souls are told to "rest" until others should be killed (Rev 6:11). This 'rest' applies to those who are dead. They are said to be witnesses to God's word and white robes were given them. 

Obviously, this is a language that applies to those who are saved, not those who are lost. John writes concerning them, "Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord from henceforth: Yea, saith the Spirit, that they may rest from their labors; and their works do follow them" (Rev 14:13). The dead are asleep or resting. The plead for justice is finally answered when the seven last plagues are poured out (Rev 16:5-7).
kb.bible-questions.death-and-immortality.suicide-bible-texts.content:
God speaks to us through Scripture and says, "Do you not know that you are God's temple and that God's Spirit dwells in you? If anyone destroys God's temple, God will destroy him. For God's temple is holy, and you are that temple." (1 Corinthians 3:16-17)
